courses.title: TypeScript Fundamentals v3
courses.summary: By adding static types to the JavaScript programming language, TypeScript delivers a rich and productive code authoring and review experience, while catching entire categories of bugs at compile time instead of runtime. In this workshop, you'll learn everything you need to know in order to confidently and successfully use TypeScript to build a modern JavaScript app.

courses.title: Intermediate TypeScript
courses.summary:
It's relatively easy to get started with TypeScript, but the learning curve
becomes much steeper once things become more complex and abstract. This workshop
teaches you how to leverage TypeScript's strengths to provide clarity
in the face of complexity, while protecting your codebase and team
from it's weaknesses.

node.excerpt: What is TypeScript? TypeScript is a syntactic superset of JavaScript An open source programming language, maintained by Microsoft The…

frontmatter.description:
We'll discuss the goals and agenda of this course, and how to get up and
running with the workshop project in 2 minutes or less.

frontmatter.title: Hello TypeScript
frontmatter.description:
In this unit, we will get hands on with our first TypeScript program and the
compiler CLI command.

frontmatter.title: Variables and Values
frontmatter.description:
We will begin our study of the TypeScript language with simple variables
and functions.

frontmatter.title: Objects, Arrays and Tuples
frontmatter.description:
Now that we know how to type simple variables and functions, let's make things
a bit more interesting with collections: in JavaScript this includes Objects and Arrays.

frontmatter.title: Structural vs. Nominal Types
frontmatter.description:
In this unit, we will explore how TypeScript is fundamentally different from
nominal type systems, such as the ones found in Java and C++.

Union and Intersection Types, Conceptually Union and intersection types can conceptually be thought of as logical boolean operators

frontmatter.title: Union and Intersection Types
frontmatter.description:
We will discuss and explore TypeScript's union and intersection types,
which are effectively "AND" and "OR" boolean logic operators for types.

node.excerpt:
TypeScript provides two mechanisms for centrally defining types and giving them
useful and meaningful names: interfaces and type aliases. We…

frontmatter.title: Interfaces and Type Aliases
frontmatter.description:
TypeScript provides two mechanisms for centrally defining types and giving them
useful and meaningful names: interfaces and type aliases. We will study both 
concepts in depth, and explain when it makes sense to use each.

Let’s put our knowledge to the test, by defining a type

frontmatter.title: JSON types
frontmatter.description:
We will take on our first challenge together: defining types
that describe any valid JSON value

frontmatter.title: Functions
frontmatter.description:
So far, we have dealt with function argument and return types. There
are a few more in-depth features we need to cover, including
multiple function heads and callable types.

node.excerpt:
TypeScript classes add some powerful and important features on top
of traditional JavaScript classes. In this unit, we will take a closer…

frontmatter.title: Classes
frontmatter.description:
TypeScript classes add some powerful and important features on top
of traditional JavaScript classes. In this unit, we will take a close look
class fields, access modifier keywords and more!

node.excerpt: Types describe sets of allowed values Let’s imagine that types describe a set of allowed values that a value might be. For example x could…

frontmatter.title: Top and bottom types
frontmatter.description:
Top types can be anything, bottom types can't be anything. We will also look
at three "extreme types" in TypeScript: any, unknown and never.

node.excerpt:
We’ve explored built-in type guards like typeof and instanceof,
but there’s a lot more power in type guards, including the ability
to define…

frontmatter.title: Type guards and narrowing
frontmatter.description:
We have explored built-in type guards like typeof and instanceof,
but there's a lot more power in type guards, including the ability
to define your own!

node.excerpt:
There are situations where we have to plan for, and deal with
the possibility that values are null or undefined. In this chapter

frontmatter.title: Nullish values
frontmatter.description:
There are situations where we have to plan for, and deal with
the possibility that values are null or undefined. In this chapter, 
we will dive deep into null, undefined, definite assignment,
and the non-null assertion operator.

frontmatter.title: Generics
frontmatter.description:
Generics allow us to parameterize types, which unlocks great opportunity
to reuse types broadly across a TypeScript project.

node.excerpt:
Let’s put our newfound knowledge around generics to the test by building out
some higher-order functions that operate on dictionaries

frontmatter.title: Dictionary map, filter and reduce
frontmatter.description:
Many of us use array the higher-order functions map, filter and reduce
quite often. Let's build out similar utilities that operate on dictionaries!

frontmatter.title: Declaration Merging
frontmatter.description:
In order to truly understand how types and values "stack" on
each other, we'll first tackle the concept of declaration merging.
Often when people grasp how TypeScript handles this, they never look
at the language the same way again

pageContext.title: TypeScript Fundamentals v3
pageContext.summary: By adding static types to the JavaScript programming language, TypeScript delivers a rich and productive code authoring and review experience, while catching entire categories of bugs at compile time instead of runtime. In this workshop, you'll learn everything you need to know in order to confidently and successfully use TypeScript to build a modern JavaScript app.
